message_1: Consider the function f(x) = x^(4/3) - x^(2/3) defined on the interval [0,1]. Determine whether the function is smooth on this interval. If it is smooth, determine the derivative of the function.
message_2:
A function is considered smooth if it has continuous derivatives of all orders on the given interval. To check if the function f(x) = x^(4/3) - x^(2/3) is smooth on the interval [0,1], we will first find its derivative.

Using the power rule for differentiation, we have:

f'(x) = d/dx (x^(4/3) - x^(2/3))
f'(x) = (4/3)x^(1/3) - (2/3)x^(-1/3)

Now we need to check if f'(x) is continuous on the interval [0,1]. The function f'(x) is continuous everywhere except possibly at x = 0, since the term x^(-1/3) has a negative exponent. To check the continuity at x = 0, we can take the limit as x approaches 0:

lim (x -> 0) [(4/3)x^(1/3) - (2/3)x^(-1/3)]

Using L'Hopital's rule, we differentiate the numerator and denominator with respect to x:

lim (x -> 0) [(4/9)x^(-2/3) - (-2/9)x^(-4/3)] / 1

Now, as x approaches 0, both terms in the limit go to 0, so the limit exists and is equal to 0. Therefore, f'(x) is continuous on the interval [0,1].

Since the first derivative f'(x) is continuous on the interval [0,1], the function f(x) = x^(4/3) - x^(2/3) is smooth on this interval. The derivative of the function is:

f'(x) = (4/3)x^(1/3) - (2/3)x^(-1/3)
